Award.AwardTitle: Ecological effects of clonal interference in a changing environment
Award.AbstractNarration:
This research will advance our understanding of how evolution proceeds and what the maximum rate of evolutionary change might be, which is relevant to understanding whether populations will be able to adapt fast enough to avoid extinction in today's rapidly and globally changing environment. Recent evidence suggests that the fact that many genes reside on the same stretches of DNA makes it difficult for natural selection to act effectively on each one, in a phenomenon known as clonal interference. This limits the maximum speed of evolution, and in a changing environment, populations that evolve too slowly go extinct. This study will address these questions through mathematical models that will calculate the impact of clonal interference on extinction and analyze the nature of competition. This research project also will provide training for undergraduate students, including individuals from groups underrepresented in the sciences, and education for the general public through public lectures, a popular science book, and Wikipedia articles.

Recent evidence suggests that high levels of linkage disequilibrium imply that recombination is slow to bring adaptive mutations together on the same genetic background. Different adaptive genotypes compete, causing many adaptations to be lost instead of fixed. To address this topic of slow adaptation due to clonal interference leading to extinction in a changing environment, the researcher will develop mathematical models of evolutionary rescue (adaptive escape from extinction). The researcher proposes a new three dimensional fitness scheme: r-selection for absolute growth speed at low population density, K-selection for absolute efficiency of resource use, and c-selection for relative competitive ability at high population density. This 3D scheme has significant advantages over past 2D schemes, e.g., r vs. K, relative vs. absolute, hard vs. soft, groups vs. individuals. This novel 3D (and extensible) model will be developed and applied to existing model systems and data. Each adaptive mutation affects one or more fitness dimensions, with both tradeoffs and synergies possible. Common combinations indicate natural axes of mutation and adaptation. Preliminary data suggest a natural axis of density-independent fitness, along which environmental change lowers both r and K in equal proportions, while subsequent adaptation (evolutionary rescue) increases both. Adaptation in the presence of clonal interference will be modeled in this dimension alone, and also in the presence of a second dimension. The latter will show how mutations fuelling the relative arms race of c-selection might contribute to extinction via clonal interference with evolutionary rescue along an absolute fitness axis.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project achieved its two scientific aims. First, we used mathematical models to clarify the distinction between different kinds of advantages or “fitness” that lead to evolutionary change by natural selection. Some kinds of fitness make an absolute contribution to helping a small population expand into an unoccupied space, while others make an individual a better relative competitor in a crowded population. Our work shows that standard mathematical models of just a single kind of fitness break down when the size of the population is not at equilibrium. Our model provides a replacement in those circumstances. It also clarifies the mechanisms that can maintain multiple different types in the same population when each type is advantageous at different times.

Second, we used a “microevolutionary” mathematical model of population genetics to make predictions on the longer “macroevolutionary” timescales of population extinction. Specifically, we found that new species go extinct more readily than established species (a prediction that is supported by the fossil record), and that extinction via the accumulation of many small environmental degradation events can appear the same as catastrophic extinction from a single event (providing a note of caution when interpreting apparent catastrophic extinction of a single species in the fossil record).

Undergraduate work looked at patterns of evolutionary change when sex occurs only occasionally rather than every generation, which is a typical pattern of sex for microbes and for many other species. We found a strikingly uneven pattern, where evolution makes sudden large jumps forward and then stalls while genetic variation takes time to build back up.

As a step toward combining our main two aims, and studying extinction when both relative and absolute kinds of competitions are present, we modeled evolution when two similar kinds of competition occur at the same time. This work formed a bridge between quantitative genetics, a field that looks at continuous variation in organismal traits and ignores most genetic details, and population genetics, a field that is focused on details at the genetic level. One important genetic detail is “clonal interference”, which means that two beneficial mutations occurring in two different individuals may compete with each other for a long time before recombination manages to bring them together in the same individual. We found that patterns of correlations between traits that are normally attributed to functional trade-offs can also be generated in the absence of such tradeoffs, simply as a result of clonal interference during rapid adaptation.

Two first-generation-college Hispanic students were trained as part of conducting research. We also ran two Wikipedia Edit-a-thons that directly disseminated evolutionary biology knowledge to the interested public, and involved more scientists in editing Wikipedia. A trade book extending the ideas of relative and absolute fitness to economics and finance was also published.
